list_page_teaser: American Presidents, just like any other group of individuals, have different personalities.  Learn how the images of some popular and recent presidents reflect their idealism, decisiveness, and other qualities.
description_html:
Which politicians – ☺ if any ☺ – are your favorites? How does your personality compare to theirs?

This gallery contains a few spiritual portraits of our presidents in the 1700s and 1800s. If you know your four-letter type, perhaps you can see similarities between your personality and that of your favorite president — assuming you have one!
story_html:
I frequently wonder whether an individual's personality type has any bearing on how they lean politically. As an idealist, I definitely admire idealistic presidents, such as Jefferson and Lincoln.

Some of these portraits are based on the four-letter type from David Keirsey's book, Presidential Temperament. Thus, the score used to create these is based on fixed percentages, and therefore these images convey limited information and insight compared to other portraits on this site.

For more about this, check out David Keirsey's book. It covers this topic in depth!

I plan to update these images at some point, but first want to focus on adding some images for more recent presidents.

To keep up to date and learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: George Washington (Keirsey.com)
image_list.subtitle_html: 1st President of the USA - Apr. 30, 1789 to Mar. 4, 1797
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: This spiritual portrait of George Washington shows that he was logical and pragmatic.  These qualities made him a good soldier and a strong leader.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Washington's rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.  He was a strong leader and his tendency to be logical enabled him to keep a cool head during the many trials and difficulties he expereicned in leading the Continental Army during the American Revolution.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Washington's tendency to be down-to-earth.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.  Being able to keep track of things like the number of men and the supplies they would need contributed greatly to his ability to be a great leader.
image_list.story_intro_html: In his book Please Understand Me II, David Keirsey picks George Washington to represent the archetypal ESTJ. His decisiveness, realism, and ....
image_list.story_html:
In his book Please Understand Me II, David Keirsey picks George Washington to represent the archetypal ESTJ. His decisiveness, realism, and attention to details served him well during difficult times, such as those at Valley Forge.

Note that this is a 'generic' image, based on fixed percentages.

image_list.title: Thomas Jefferson (Keirsey.com)
image_list.subtitle_html: 3rd President of the USA - Mar. 4, 1801 to Mar. 4, 1809
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: This spiritual portrait of Thomas Jefferson shows that he was, like Lincoln, an idealist who preferred to make logical decisions.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Jefferson's tendency to be logical.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  This preference is evident in his interests in topics such as philosophy, science, and technology.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Jefferson's idealism.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  This tendency is evident in his authoring of the Declaration of Independence and his support of religious freedom and being able to see the possibility that people with different religious beliefs could overcome their differences and learn to live together.
image_list.story_intro_html: I find Jefferson to be remarkable in many ways, certainly at least in part because his name was the same as mine ('Tom') and he was ....
image_list.story_html:
I find Jefferson to be remarkable in many ways, certainly at least in part because his name was the same as mine ('Tom') and he was from Virginia (where I grew up). David Keirsey identifies Jefferson as an INTP, and that certainly seems reasonable to me.

Although we should all be familiar with the Declaration of Independence, a letter he wrote to Maria Cosway in the spring of 1786 articulates quite well the distinction between Thinking (Green) and Feeling (Red) functions in these four-letter-types.

Entitled My Head and My Heart, it demonstrates how he was well aware of, and struggled with, the dichotomy between reason and emotion over a century before Carl Jung wrote about them in his book, General Description of the Types. This is a wonderful letter, and I strongly encourage you to read it!

Note that this is a portrait of a 'generic' INTP, and is based on fixed percentages. Based on this letter I believe that Jefferson's F-T score on the quiz could be closer to 50%/50% than the 58%/42% shown here.

image_list.title: Andrew Jackson
image_list.subtitle_html: 7th President of the USA - Mar. 4, 1829 to Mar. 4, 1837
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: This spiritual portrait of Andrew Jackson shows he was very decisive, prefering to use logic but capable of using emotion when making decisions.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Jackson's dominant trait, his objectivity.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait in his leadership ability and complete intolerance of insubordination in his ranks.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Jackson's auxiliary trait, his realism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.
image_list.story_html:
Andrew Jackson was born on March 14, 1767. Both of his parents had only recently immigrated to America from Ireland, bringing with them his two older brothers, Hugh (born in 1763) and Robert (born in 1764).

Andrew never met his father, who died in an accident less than a month before he was born. He then lost his oldest brother Hugh to heatstroke after a battle in the Revolutionary War in June of 1779.

Still in their teens, Andrew and Robert began serving as a couriers during the Revolutionary War in 1780. In 1781 the British captured the two, and during their imprisonment Andrew famously refused to clean a general's boots.

Andrew's mother was able to get him and Robert released, but she and his brother died of illnesses in 1981. At 14 years old, Andrew had lost all of his immediate family, and he blamed the British for it.

These early experiences made Andrew Jackson tough, decisive, and loyal to the American dream of liberty and government of the people.

As long as our government is administered for the good of the people, and is regulated by their will; as long as it secures to us the rights of persons and of property, liberty of conscience, and of the press, it will be worth defending.

In the War of 1812 — specifically the Creek War — this toughness led his men to call him Old Hickory. His courage in the Battle of New Orleans made him a national hero. These experiences also made him a realist:

But you must remember, my fellow-citizens, that eternal vigilance by the people is the price of liberty, and that you must pay the price if you wish to secure the blessing.

Jackson could be incredibly cruel, as when he signed the Indian Removal Act. He could also be very warm, as the following quote reveals:

Heaven will be no heaven to me if I do not meet my wife there.

Andrew Jackson's all-or-nothing decisiveness is plainly visible in the large amounts of Green and Red in his spiritual portrait, and the Yellow represents is realism.

The personality profile for this image is based on the video Andrew Jackson: Good, Evil and the Presidency, which is available on youtube.

image_list.title: Abraham Lincoln (Keirsey.com)
image_list.subtitle_html: 16th President of the USA - Mar. 4, 1861 to Apr. 15, 1865
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: This spiritual portrait of Abraham Lincoln shows he was, like Jefferson, an idealist who preferred to make logical decisions.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Lincoln's preference for logic over emotion.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  His ability to reason logically surely served him well during the days he spent as a lawyer.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Lincoln's iNtuition.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  He is certainly most famous for his ability to see the possibility of the United States as being a country without slaves.
image_list.story_intro_html:
David Keirsey identifies Abraham Lincoln as an INTP, and this is certainly reasonable.

His Idealism is evident in his ....
image_list.story_html:
David Keirsey identifies Abraham Lincoln as an INTP, and this is certainly reasonable.

His Idealism is evident in his speeches, such as the Gettysburg Address. In this short speech he shows how his temperament is similar to Jefferson's by reiterating the important principles outlined in Jefferson's Declaration of Independence.

One of the most famous phrases in this speech, in which Lincoln declares that government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth certainly shows his ability to see a possibile future that many others obviously had difficulty comprehending.

Note that this is an image of a 'generic' personality, and is based on fixed percentages.

image_list.title: Ulysses S. Grant
image_list.subtitle_html: 18th President of the USA - Mar. 4, 1869 to Mar. 4, 1877
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: This spiritual portrait of Ulysses S. Grant shows that he is logical and pragmatic.  These qualities mean he makes a good soldier.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Grant's very slight preference for pragmatism over idealism.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  This preference is very slight and would be more evident in his role as a soldier than it would be in his role as president.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Grant's very slight preference for making logical decisions.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  This preference is very slight and would be more evident in his role as a soldier than it would be in his role as a father.
image_list.story_intro_html:
This profile of Ulysses S. Grant is based on the nearly four-hour-long Ulysses S. Grant Warrior President DVD.

Although my process identifies ....
image_list.story_html:
This profile of Ulysses S. Grant is based on the nearly four-hour-long Ulysses S. Grant Warrior President DVD.

Although my process identifies him as an ISTJ, it shows very slight preferences in all four pairs of opposites. Interestingly, one source identifies him as an xNTJ and another identifies him as an ISFJ.

I believe it is much more important to recognize that his preferences were slight than it is to agree on a specific set of four letters. Although it can be interesting to speculate what type historical characters were, it's important to realize that ultimately it is purely speculation.

It's clear to me that he was an Introvert. Time and again historians in the video mention how he liked to be alone to reflect on things and could be hard to read.

He felt he was at his best when he was alone. He liked to think through things. He liked quiet time.
- Donald L. Miller, Historian

Although failing to immediately notice certain facts can quickly get a soldier in trouble, a general who can see both the forest and the trees is in a better position than his peers who can't see the big picture.

A general who can ride around the battlefield, and by glimpsing: men advancing over there, troops forming up over here, artillery firing somewhere in the distance, and can put all of these pieces together in his head, and see what is actually happening, through the smoke, that is a General who has an extraordinary gift.
- Geoffrey Perret, Biographer

Indeed, Grant certainly had ideals. Before the war, he set a slave free rather than sell him, and after the war he wanted nothing more than to find peace with the plains indians and stubborn racist southerners. But this does not mean he had his head in the clouds:

Having lunch with Grant is like having pork and beans with Julius Ceasar.
- Mark Twain

Twain's quote makes me wish we had time machines and could visit with people who are no longer with us. Rather than long for things we will never have, it's probably best to just be grateful for the next best thing: having videos such as this one that we can watch!
